{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Liston B. Ramsey Regional Activity Center | nickname = "The Lair" | image = [[File:Ramsey Regional Activity Center in Cullowhee, NC.jpg|300px]] | caption = Liston B. Ramsey Regional Activity Center | location = 92 Catamount Road
Cullowhee, NC 28723 USA | broke_ground = October 1982 | built = | opened = April 10, 1986 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Western Carolina University]] | operator = Western Carolina University | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]16.3 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|16300000|1986}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Crain & Anderson, Inc.
Foy & Lee Associates{{cite web |title=Board of Trustees Meeting|url=http://www.wcu.edu/24359.asp|publisher=Western Carolina University|date=August 26, 1981|accessdate=April 28, 2012}} | structural engineer = [[Walter P Moore Engineers and Consultants|Walter P Moore]]{{cite web |title=Arenas|url=http://www.walterpmoore.com/proj2_2.htm|publisher=Walter P Moore|accessdate=November 10, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000708022900/http://www.walterpmoore.com/proj2_2.htm|archivedate=July 8, 2000}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Western Carolina Catamounts]]
(men's and women's basketball & volleyball) | seating_capacity = 7,826 (basketball)
8,556 (concerts) }} The '''Liston B. Ramsey Regional Activity Center''' is a 7,826-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Cullowhee, North Carolina|Cullowhee]], in the [[U.S. state]] of [[North Carolina]], and is home to the [[Western Carolina University]] [[Western Carolina Catamounts|Catamounts]] [[basketball]] and [[volleyball]] teams. It is also named "THE LAIR". It is a state owned facility (by the University) and offers the largest [[seating capacity]] inside the [[Charlotte, North Carolina|Charlotte]]–[[Atlanta]]–[[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville]] triangle.{{cite web |title=Entertainment|url=http://ramsey.wcu.edu/entertainment.htm|publisher=Western Carolina University|accessdate=April 28, 2012}} In addition to the arena, the Ramsey Center includes five racquetball courts, two basketball courts, a walking/jogging track, and lighted outdoor rollerblade/skateboard facilities for students. Features not in use at this time include an indoor firing range and an outdoor-lighted [[ice skating]] facility. ==History== The Liston B. Ramsey Regional Activity Center was completed in April, 1986 and was dedicated on December 6 of that same year before a standing-room only crowd of 8,114 as Western Carolina hosted North Carolina State on the men's basketball hardwood. The first official game in the new building took place two-days prior as the women's squad downed Mars Hill on December 4, 1986, by a score of 65-61. In 1999, the Ramsey Center also became the home venue for the WCU volleyball team.{{cite web |title=Liston B. Ramsey Regional Activity Center|url=http://www.catamountsports.com/facilities/ramsey-regional-center.html|publisher=Western Carolina University Athletics|accessdate=February 7, 2014}} ==Notable events== Such entertainment acts as Aerosmith, Alabama, Rascal Flatts, Montgomery Gentry, Eric Church, The Band Perry, Tim Mcgraw, The Gaither Homecoming, Billy Currington, Bon Jovi (in 1986), Chicago, Fabolous, Jason Aldean, Lady Antebellum, Lorrie Morgan and Nappy Roots have played at the Ramsey Center. Other featured events include the Harlem Globetrotters, WcW Wrestling, Monster Jam, appearances by the New York City Opera, Los Angeles Ballet and the Acting Company. Lectures from famous personalities like Pat Summitt and former presidential candidate, Bob Dole have taken place at the Ramsey Center. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://ramsey.wcu.edu}} {{Western Carolina University}} {{Western Carolina Catamounts men's basketball navbox}} {{Southern Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{North Carolina NCAA Division I women's college volleyball venues navbox}} {{WNC sports venues}} {{coord|35.303752|-83.18234|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Western Carolina Catamounts]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jackson County, North Carolina]] [[Category:Basketball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:1986 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1986]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] {{NorthCarolina-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.text:
{{essay-like|date=October 2016}}
{{Infobox sport | name = Women's surfing | image = | caption = | union = [[International Surfing Association]] | nickname = | first = | country/region = Worldwide | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = | mgender = Yes, separate competitions | category = | equipment = | venue = | olympic = Yes, as of the [[2020 Summer Olympics|2020 Olympics]] | paralympic = }}
The earliest recorded incidence of '''women's surfing''' concerns the mythical Kelea. [[Keleanohoanaapiapi|Kelea]] was born of [[Kingdom of Hawaii|royalty]] in [[Maui]], it is believed she out-surfed riders of both genders. A few centuries years pass until the mid-late 1800s, when Thrum’s Hawaiian Annual reported that women in ancient Hawaii surfed in equal numbers and frequently better than men.<ref>{{cite news|title= Why Are Surf Magazines Erasing Women?|website=Theestablishment.co|date=|url= http://www.theestablishment.co/2015/11/09/why-are-surf-magazines-erasing-women/|accessdate=2016-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Andrea Moller makes history for women's big wave surfing|publisher= [[Surfer]]|date=|url= http://www.surfertoday.com/surfing/12618-andrea-moller-makes-history-for-womens-big-wave-surfing|accessdate=2016-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Inside the Curl: Surfing's Surprising History|publisher= [[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]]|date=|url= http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2013/08/130803-surfing-surprising-history-hawaiian-culture-extreme-sports/|accessdate=2016-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Coco Ho On The State Of Women’s Surfing|publisher= [[Surfing]]|date=|url= http://www.surfingmagazine.com/photos/coco-ho-state-womens-surfing/#8yUJXmlgaXR8AeH3.99|accessdate=2016-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-DWQSYRx4MUC&pg=PR21&lpg=PR21&dq=history+of+women's+surfing&source=bl&ots=UciV5AVwHX&sig=wFjDHSNkMjKLs2iA0e-frUiDo1g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjS58ikydTLAhXDthoKHebNAck4FBDoAQhJMAg#v=onepage&q=history%20of%20women's%20surfing&f=false |title=The Encyclopedia of Surfing - Matt Warshaw - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-03-23}}</ref> [[Women's surfing in Australia]] has a popular following amongst female participants.
In the [[muslim world]] many women are taking up surfing.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/great-reads/la-fg-c1-bangladesh-surf-girls-20160404-story.html |title=Bangladeshi surfer girls go against the cultural tide |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2016-04-10 |accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Iran's New Revolution|publisher= Mpora|date=|url= http://mpora.com/longform/easkey-britton-surf-revolution-iran#2DGtZkFV6vVxcGmj.97|accessdate=2016-03-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2015-06-18/iran-where-women-schooled-men-surfing |title=In Iran, where the women school the men on surfing | Public Radio International |publisher=Pri.org |date=2015-06-18 |accessdate=2016-03-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Muslim women making waves and breaking stereotypes|website=Drift|date=|url= http://www.driftsurfing.eu/muslim-women-making-waves-breaking-stereotypes/|accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Riding the Wave of Feminism: Meet the Female Surfers of Iran|website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|date=|url= https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/riding-the-wave-of-feminism-meet-the-female-surfers-of-iran|accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surfermag.com/features/iran-female-surf-revolution/#4mZZuErMtawm2tyr.97 |title=Iran's Female Surf Pioneers | SURFER Magazine |website=Surfermag.com |date=2014-12-01 |accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref>
Women’s surfing has made an increase in popularity over the last 50 years.<ref>{{cite news|author=Harriet Agerholm |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/bangladeshi-surfer-girls-who-refuse-accept-sexism-women-rights-work-marry-a7227476.html |title=Girls in Bangladesh are expected to work or marry. These girls surf instead |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=2016-09-06 |accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref>
==Origin== The origin of surfing was most likely started in New Guinea.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ahrens |first=Chris |url=http://www.thecoastnews.com/2011/03/03/a-short-history-of-womens-surfing/ |title=A short history of women’s surfing – The Coast News Group |website=Thecoastnews.com |date=2016-10-10 |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref> It was a sport full of culture, fun, and adventure. Surfing was used to explore the oceans and to have fun becoming a part of nature. It spread from New Guinea to Hawaii. It is mostly known to be practiced in Hawaii and the surrounding islands, but it has spread to the rest of the continents. It was not widely accepted by Europeans because it took time away from working and labor, although they enjoyed the excitement of seeing the action of surfing.<ref>{{cite web|author=Isaiah Walker |url=http://www.theinertia.com/surf/women-movement-ancient-hawaiian-surf-lore/ |title=Womentum: The Women's Movement (in Context) |publisher=The Inertia |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
==Turning points== The California Golden Girls played a huge part in the making Women’s surfing featured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofwomensurfing.com/the-california-golden-girls/ |title=History of Women's Surfing : The California Golden Girls |website=Historyofwomensurfing.com |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref> They were pivotal in the 1970 to the 1980 to making people aware of the sport and they gave a face to the once widely known “Men’s Sport.”
==Regions== In the United States, the most common places you will find women’s surfing would be California and Hawaii because they have the best conditions for surfing. Although you are able to surf in any place that has waves, surfing is mostly found all across the world from Peru, Australia, Indonesia, South Africa, France, Philippines, Ecuador, and anywhere else that has a shore and waves coming in. Although surfing can be found anywhere, there are a lot of things that affect the waves. Tide, time of day, storms miles off shore, and weather can all affect the strength of the waves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theinspireinitiative.org/tag/history-of-womens-surfing-2/ |title=history of women's surfing Archives - The Inspire Initiative™ |website=Theinspireinitiative.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
==Women surfers and quotations== [[Bethany Hamilton]]: She is an American surfer that despite getting attacked by a shark while surfing, and having her arm bitten off, she did not let that stop her from continuing her career as a surfer. She continued to get better and won many competitions following her attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.surfertoday.com/surfing/8769-the-inspirational-quotes-by-bethany-hamilton |title=The inspirational quotes by Bethany Hamilton |website=Surfertoday.com |date=2003-10-31 |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
''“It's hard for me to describe the joy I felt after I stood up and rode wave in for the first time after the attack. I was incredibly thankful and happy inside. The tiny bit of doubt that would sometimes tell me you'll never surf again was gone in one wave.” –Bethany Hamilton''
Marge Calhoun: She was a woman surfer who pioneered surfing in Hawaii. She is considered the first women surfing champion. She was indicted into the surfing hall of fame in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://encyclopediaofsurfing.com/entries/calhoun-family |title=Entries – Calhoun Family – Encyclopedia Of Surfing |website=Encyclopediaofsurfing.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
[[Stephanie Gilmore]]: “Fear - It's a fine line between that and pushing yourself. You definitely reach new heights when you push. But fear is good. Fear keeps us alive. If we didn't have it, we'd be doing crazy things and getting in sticky situations.” –Stephanie Gilmore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azquotes.com/author/30677-Stephanie_Gilmore |title=TOP 11 QUOTES BY STEPHANIE GILMORE |publisher=A-Z Quotes |date=1988-01-29 |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
[[Carissa Moore]]: “We all strive to find something unique and special that we are passionate about that separates us from the rest.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.carissamoore.com/ |title=Carissa Moore |publisher=Carissa Moore |date=2016-04-30 |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
[[Maya Gabeira]] is a big wave surfer who was born in Rio de Janeiro. She has five Billabong XXL Global Big Wave Award titles received from 2007–2010 and in 2012. She also won the 2009 ESPY Award for Best Female Action Sport Athlete.<ref>{{cite web|last=Binns |first=Chris |url=http://www.redbull.com/us/en/surfing/athletes/1331575111951/maya-gabeira |title=Maya Gabeira: Surfing – Official Athlete Page |website=Redbull.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-27}}</ref>
[[Courtney Conlogue]] is a 25 year old American professional surfer. In an interview with ESPN she outlined what it takes to be a professional surfer. "I think some people perceive surfing as just a lifestyle sport. This will be my sixth year competing professionally on the World Tour, and to be involved in something like this goes to show that we do fine-tune our bodies in order to be as strong as we can when we enter the water. During the offseason, I train three to five days a week, and then I train every day in the water. Depending on the way the swell is -- because our sport is based on Mother Nature -- when the waves are good, I surf probably six hours a day."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/article/16426114/surfer-courtney-conlogue-talks-body-love-breathing-underwater-espn-body-issue|title=Surfer Courtney Conlogue shares what it takes to be a pro surfer|last=Ain|first=Morty|date=26 June 2016|website=www.espn.com|publisher=ESPN|access-date=1 December 2016}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *Douglas Booth, « From Bikinis to Boardshorts: "Wahines" and the Paradoxes of Surfing Culture », ''Journal of Sport History'', vol. 28, n°1, spring 2001, pp. 3-22. *A. Gabbard, ''Girl in the curl: A century of women in surfing'', Seal Press, 2000. *{{fr}} Anne-Sophie Sayeux, « Femmes surfeuses, paroles d'hommes surfeurs : petits arrangements dans l'ordre des genres », in ''L'Harmattan 2ème congrès international de la Société de Sociologie du Sport en Langue Française'', L'Harmattan, Paris, 2007, pp.85-100. *L. Heywood, in Anita Harris (ed.), « Third-wave feminism, the global economy, and women's surfing: Sport as stealth feminism in girls' surf culture », ''Next Wave Cultures: Feminism, Subcultures, Activism'', 2008. *Krista Comer, ''Surfer Girls in the New World Order'', Duke University Press, 2010.

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Workers' Stadium
工人体育场 | nickname = 工体| image = [[File:Workers Stadium.jpg|250px|Beijing Workers Stadium]]| location = [[Chaoyang District, Beijing|Chaoyang District]], [[Beijing]] | broke_ground = | opened = 1959 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Beijing Municipal Bureau of Sports{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} | operator = {{bullet list|Beijing Workers Sports Services Centre{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}| [[IRENA Group]]{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}}} | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | capacity = 66,161 | tenants = [[Beijing Guoan]]
[[China national football team]] }} {{chinese |s=工人体育场 |t=工人體育場 |p=Gōngrén Tǐyùchǎng |order=st |mi={{IPAc-cmn|g|ong|1|r|en|2|-|t|i|3|yu|4|ch|ang|3}} |w=Kūngrén T'ǐyǜch'ǎng |myr=Gūngrén Tǐyùchǎng }} [[File:Workers Stadium - satellite image (1967-09-20).jpg|thumb|Satellite image of Workers' Stadium. (1967-09-20)]] The '''Workers' Stadium''' ({{zh|s={{linktext|工|人|体|育|场}}|t={{linktext|工|人|體|育|場}}|p=Gōngrén Tǐyùcháng}}), often called '''Gongti''' or '''Gong Ti''', is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in the [[Chaoyang District, Beijing|Chaoyang District]] of north-eastern [[Beijing]], [[People's Republic of China|China]]. It is mostly used for [[Football at the 2008 Summer Olympics|football (soccer)]] matches.{{cite web|url=http://en.beijing2008.cn/venues/wst/index.shtml|title=Beijing2008.cn profile.|author=|date=|website=beijing2008.cn}} The stadium was built in 1959 and was last renovated in 2004 (the concrete structure was strengthened, a new rotating display screen and energy-saving devices were installed). It has a capacity of 66,161 and covers a land area of 350,000 square meters. It is one of the [[Ten Great Buildings]] constructed in 1959 for the 10th anniversary of the [[People's Republic of China]]. During the 1950s and 1960s mass executions were carried out in the stadium {{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}. ==History== The stadium was the main venue for the [[1990 Asian Games]], where the opening and closing ceremonies were held. Some high attendance matches of the [[Beijing Guo'an]] football club are held at the stadium. In 1993 the stadium was host to a slew of [[World Records]] set by the world-leading group of Chinese distance runners at the 7th Edition of the Chinese National Games, the most famous being international stars and world champions [[Wang Junxia]] and [[Qu Yunxia]], who had dominated the 1993 World Championships a month before. The stadium holds claim to the fastest women's [[1500 m]] time ever recorded of 3:50.46, the fastest women's [[3000 m]] of 8:06.11 and the fastest women's [[10,000 m]] of 29:31.78. These world records still stand today and are arguably the stadium's biggest claim to fame.{{cite web|url=http://tv.sohu.com/20090719/n265320285.shtml|title=视频：新中国日记 传奇马家军的成名之战-搜狐视频|author=|date=|website=tv.sohu.com}} The next year, the stadium was partially demolished and renovated as part of China's bid for the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Olympic Games]], which ultimately failed. The stadium continued to be a mainstay of Beijing sports into the 21st century, being the [[2004 AFC Asian Cup Final|Grand Final]] venue of [[2004 AFC Asian Cup]]. For the [[2008 Summer Olympics]], it hosted the football quarter-finals and semi-finals, and the women's gold medal final. The stadium was scheduled to host the first ever [[National Football League|NFL]] game played in China, a preseason game between the [[Seattle Seahawks]] and the [[New England Patriots]] on August 8, 2007. However, the [[China Bowl (NFL)|China Bowl]] was canceled in April 2007. The reasons given were that the NFL wanted to devote all its resources to the scheduled regular season game between the [[Miami Dolphins]] and the [[New York Giants]], to be played in [[London]] on October 28, 2007. The stadium was the host for the 2009 [[Barclays Asia Trophy]] on 29 July and 31 July 2009, featuring [[Beijing Guoan]], and [[Premier League]] clubs [[Tottenham Hotspur]], [[West Ham United]] and [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]. It also hosted [[FC Bayern Munich]]'s pre-season China Tour of 2012, during which the [[Bundesliga]] club had a friendly match with [[Beijing Guoan]]. The areas north ([[Sanlitun]]), east, and west of the stadium are popular nightlife destinations. The ''xi men'' (West Gate) offers a strip of nightclubs. The [[Workers Indoor Arena]] is located to the west of the stadium. The stadium has been used for concerts as well. Global superstar [[Mariah Carey]] began her sold-out five-show tour at the Workers Stadium, and Linkin Park played [[The Hunting Party Tour]] at July 26, 2015 in front of an audience of 60,000.{{cite web|url=http://en.yibada.com/articles/49016/20150728/linkin-park-rocks-beijing-workers-stadium.htm|title=Linkin Park Rocks Beijing Workers' Stadium|first=Francis Eduard|last=Ang|date=28 July 2015|website=yibada.com}} [[File:Beijing Workers Stadium, August 19, 2008.jpg|thumb|right|Interior during the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]]] ==Notable Events== * August 6, 1999: [[A-mei]] - Mei Li 99 * October 13, 2002: [[Glay]] - Glay One Love In Beijing, audience: 35,000 * August 28, 2004: [[Faye Wong]] - No Faye! No Live! {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Yanzigang Stadium
燕子岗体育场 | nickname = | image = JinZiGongTaiJukCoeng (NORTH GATE).jpg | image_size = 280 | location = 251 Jiangyan Rd, [[Guangzhou]], [[Guangdong]], China | coordinates = {{coord|23.078816|N|113.278614|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | built = | opened = September 1985 | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Guangzhou People's Government | operator = Guangzhou Sports Bureau | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | tenants = [[R&F FC (Hong Kong)|R&F]] (2017–)
[[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.|Guangzhou Evergrande]] Reserves (2017–) | seating_capacity = 2,000{{cite web|title=富力內地主場簡陋 200門票予港人|url=http://paper.wenweipo.com/2017/08/21/SP1708210019.htm|website=Wenweipo}} {{zh-hk icon}} }} '''Yanzigang Stadium''' ({{zh|s=燕子岗体育场|t=燕子崗體育場|p=Yānzǐgǎng Tīyùcháng|j=Jin1zi2gong1 Tai2juk6coeng4}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Guangzhou]], [[Guangdong]], China. It mainly used for campus football league and youth football championships of Guangzhou. It is the current home of [[Hong Kong Premier League]] club [[R&F FC (Hong Kong)|R&F]] as well as the [[Guangzhou Evergrande Taobao F.C.|Guangzhou Evergrande]] Reserves. ==History== Yanzigang Stadium was opened in September 1985 as the training field for football in the 1987 [[National Games of China]]. It also served as a training field for the [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup]], [[2001 National Games of China]] and [[2010 Asian Games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gzsports.gov.cn/info/1527/2969.htm|title=许瑞生副市长指示要将燕子岗体育场规划好建设好 广州市燕子岗体育场推出建设总体规划|work=Guangzhou Sports Bureau|date=2007-12-28|accessdate=2017-06-20|language=zh}} It was the home stadium of [[Guangzhou Evergrande]] youth team for the [[2011 China League Two]]. Guangzhou Evergrande Reserves moved their home stadium from Lishui Evergrande Training Base to Yanzigang Stadium in 2017. In June, [[Hong Kong Premier League]] club [[R&F (Hong Kong)|R&F]] received approval to use Yanzigang as their home stadium.{{cite web|title=富力将战港超预备队联赛|url=http://news.163.com/17/0628/04/CO074HB200018AOP.html|work=Guangzhou News|date=2017-06-28|accessdate=2017-06-28|language=zh}} ==Facilities== The stadium is situated on a 60,207m² complex which includes a 400m track, one 5 a side football pitch, one 7 a side football pitches, one natural grass and one artificial regulation size pitches. In addition, there are tennis courts, table tennis courts, six indoor badminton courts and a basketball court.{{cite web|title=燕子岗体育场|url=http://baike.baidu.com/item/%E7%87%95%E5%AD%90%E5%B2%97%E4%BD%93%E8%82%B2%E5%9C%BA|website=Baidu}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Hong Kong Premier League venues}} {{Guangzhou}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yanzigang Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Haizhu District]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Guangzhou]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1985]]
